Systematic reviews on tele-101 rehabilitation interventions after stroke have demonstrated either better or equal salutary effects on motor, 102 higher cortical, and mood disorders compared with conventional face-to-face therapy. 10 However, studies on 103 the effectiveness of tele-rehabilitation for non-stroke conditions are still lacking. Nevertheless, during 104 situations like outbreaks, tele-rehabilitation has the additional advantage of continuing rehabilitation 105 supervision remotely without risk of virus exposure. is an immunocompromising disease that increases the risk of severe 2019-nCoV infection and 109 mortality. Diabetes is also a risk factor for common conditions that require rehabilitation like cardiovascular 110 disease and stroke which themselves increase the mortality risk. Other common conditions needing 111 rehabilitation like chronic respiratory disease and cancer are also associated with higher risk of mortality from 112 2019-nCoV. Hence, our rehabilitation patients are at higher risk of severe and fatal 2019-nCoV infections. For 113 those who are capable of performing rehabilitation at home with guidance from tele-rehabilitation, this should 114 be their first option. For the rest who need centre-based or inpatient rehabilitation, we recommend fever and 115 flu symptom monitoring to separate the well from the unwell, and strict infection control measures including 116 handwashing between patients to reduce virus transmission. Patients who are symptomatic should be 117 separated from the well, quarantined and tested for 2019-nCoV, and isolated and treated if positive. Hospital 118 management should designate and prepare isolation rooms with adequate PPE and trained staff.

TABREF1.text: Wearing of PPE may be uncomfortable for HCWs, especially with N95 masks which requires greater effort to 142 breathe when worn. It may not be wise to deploy HCWs with chronic respiratory problems to hospital areas Business Continuity Plans are organizational strategies that allow the workforce to continue functioning if a significant subset of the workforce needs to be quarantined or worse, falls ill. This usually involves 152 arrangements like split teams, restricted movement and work-from-home arrangements. With the exception of 153 clerical staff and tele-rehabilitation, it is impractical for rehabilitation HCWs to work from home as our 154 discipline is very hands-on. Hence, strategies like split teams and restricted movement are more relevant in 155 rehabilitation. Split teams is complete physical division of a workforce into (usually two) sub-teams with each 156 containing the necessary skill sets to continue most of its functions if one sub-team becomes unable to work.Restricted movement is another strategy whereby the principle is every staff in a sub-team does not come in 158 physical contact with any staff from other sub-team(s) to minimise risk of cross-infection. Hospital 159 management should also review triage processes at entry points and workflows that separate high-risk from 160 low-risk areas and sub-teams. Other often forgotten issues are HCWs who are parents of young children.
